facts.text: The case is in Criminal Appellate Jurisdiction numbered Case No. 349 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLANTE JURLSDICTION Case No. 349 of 1951.

facts.text: Appeal under article 132(1) of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under article 132  1  of the Constitution of India

facts.text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 26th June, 1951 of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: from the Judgment and Order dated the 26th June, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature,at Bombay

facts.text: High Court judges are Chagla C. J. and Gajendragadkar J.

facts.text: High Court case is Criminal Application No. 345 of 1951.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on 1954 March 10 by Bose J.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. March 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Bose J.-The question in this case

facts.text: Appellant is being prosecuted for adultery under section 497 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is being prosecuted for adultery under section 497 of the Indian Penal Code. As soon as the

facts.text: As soon as the complaint was filed, appellant applied to the High Court of Bombay under article 228 to determine the constitutional question.

anchor.surface_text: As soon as the companyplaint was filed he applied to the High Court of Bombay to determine the companystitutional question mentioned above under article 228 of the Constitution.

facts.text: The High Court decided against the appellant on the constitutional question.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court decided against him but granted him a certificate under articles 132  1  and 134  1   c .

facts.text: The High Court granted certificate under articles 132(1) and 134(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court decided against him but granted him a certificate under articles 132  1  and 134  1   c . Under section 497

facts.text: Under section 497 the offence of adultery can only be committed by a man.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 497 the offence of adultery can only be companymitted by a man but in the absence of any provision to the companytrary the woman would be punishable as an abettor.

facts.text: The last sentence in section 497 provides that the wife shall not be punishable as an abettor.

anchor.surface_text: The last sentence in section 497 prohibits this. It runs- In such case the wife shall number be punishable as an abettor.

facts.text: The appellant is not a citizen of India.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is number a citizen of India. It was argued that he companyld number invoke articles 14 and 15

facts.text: It was argued that the appellant could not invoke articles 14 and 15 because he is not a citizen of India.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued that he companyld number invoke articles 14 and 15 for that reason. The High Court held otherwise.

facts.text: The High Court held that the appellant could invoke articles 14 and 15.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held otherwise.
Appeal under article 132  1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 26th June, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature,at Bombay

issues.text: Whether section 497 of the Indian Penal Code contravenes articles 14 and 15 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The question in this case is whether section 497 of the Indian Penal Code companytravenes articles 14 and 15 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether clause 3 of Article 15 is confined to beneficial provisions for women or permits provisions exempting women from punishment

anchor.surface_text: The provision companyplained of is a special provision and it is made for women, therefore it is saved by clause  3 . It was argued that clause  3  should be confined to provisions which are beneficial to women and cannot be used to give them a licence to companymit and abet crimes. We are unable to read any such restriction into the clause

arguments.claim: Sex is a sound classification and the Constitution provides for special provisions for women

anchor.surface_text: Sex is a sound classification and although there can be no discrimination in general on that ground, the Constitution itself provides for special provisions in the case of women and children.

arguments.claim: Articles 14 and 15 read together validate the impugned clause in section 497

anchor.surface_text: The two articles read together validate the impugned clause in section 497 of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.text: The two articles read together validate the impugned clause in section 497 of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 14 read harmoniously with Article 15, including clause 3 permitting special provisions for women; sex constitutes sound classification.

holdings.text: The provision complained of is a special provision and it is made for women, therefore it is saved by clause 3.

anchor.surface_text: The provision companyplained of is a special provision and it is made for women, therefore it is saved by clause  3 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of Article 15(3) exception to the exemption of wife from punishment under Section 497 IPC.

holdings.text: We are unable to read any such restriction into the clause nor are we able to agree that a provision which prohibits punishment is tantamount to a licence to commit the offence of which punishment has been prohibited.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to read any such restriction into the clause number are we able to agree that a provision which prohibits punishment is tantamount ,to a licence to companymit the offence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation rejects limitation of Article 15(3) to only beneficial provisions; exemption from punishment not a licence to offend.

holdings.text: Article 14 is general and must be read with the other provisions which set out the ambit of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 is general and must be read with the other provisions which set out the ambit of fundamental rights.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction requires Article 14 to be interpreted in light of specific provisions like Article 15.

holdings.text: Sex is a sound classification and although there can be no discrimination in general on that ground, the Constitution itself provides for special provisions in the case of women and children.

anchor.surface_text: Sex is a sound classification and although there can be numberdiscriminate in general on that ground, the Constitution itself provides for special provisions in the case of women and children.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of reasonable classification test under Article 14; Constitution explicitly allows via Article 15(3).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acceptance of High Court's determination that non-citizens can invoke Articles 14 and 15; no reversal by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The two articles read together validate the impugned clause in section 497 of the Indian Penal Code.

outcome.relief_summary: Impugned clause of section 497 IPC validated as not contravening articles 14 and 15; appellant's constitutional challenge rejected
